body_html: I would avoid using any sync version of a function where an async version with callback is available. The sync versions suspend a thread which could lead to a deadlock if you run out of threads. It may be that by blocking you've also introduced a deadlock some other way, where the callback is waiting on something whose execution would have been triggered after the async invocation returned.
body_text: I would avoid using any sync version of a function where an async version with callback is available.  The sync versions suspend a thread which could lead to a deadlock if you run out of threads.  It may be that by blocking you've also introduced a deadlock some other way, where the callback is waiting on something whose execution would have been triggered after the async invocation returned.
body: I would avoid using any sync version of a function where an async version with callback is available.  The sync versions suspend a thread which could lead to a deadlock if you run out of threads.  It may be that by blocking you've also introduced a deadlock some other way, where the callback is waiting on something whose execution would have been triggered after the async invocation returned.
